course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Computer Organization
course.description: This is an introductory course to computer organization. The topics covered include instruction-set-design, digital design and computer arithmetic, controller and datapath design, memory systems, input-output systems, interrupts, pipelining, performance analysis, assembly language programming, and survey of advanced architectures.

reviews.author: Excalibur
reviews.title: Very light workload course among four ELEC 2000 level courses
reviews.comment_content:
Since this is just an introductory course, you will not learn much from it. First, we were introduced about the type of computers and some key points in the course.

The second part, which is quite interesting, was about the assembly language. This gave you some ideas on how variables are allocated in memory, how instructions are executed using registers and much more in slightly more detail. The slide provided by the professor was filled with many blank spaces and little explanation so you might find this chapter is the most difficult one among others. I asked my friend and found that the slide prepared by prof Kursun Volkan was more comprehensive and understandable.

The third part was about arithmetic operation. I don't think this part is useful since I already knew this from ELEC 2200 except the floating points. This chapter is not a big deal.

The fourth part was about simple performance analysis. You learnt about how the CPU performance compared by using suitable variables like CPI and MIPS. With some ideal assumptions, you were asked to do some simple numerical calculation. The math is simple trust me :), no calculus whatsoever.

The fifth part is about MIPS processor. We have learnt about different type of MIPS processors such as single cycle processor, multi-cycle processor, and pipelined processor. They have different techniques on how it manages each part of the processor in a given clock cycle. Now, you are encouraged to understand the seeming complicated diagram about how each part of the processor works. I heard that this course requires memorization but it turns out it was not as long as you understand what is going on.

Last but not least, is about memory organization. This part actually requires a little 暗記. You will know types of memory, the architecture, and the principle about caching. The caching procedure was also included.

The professor omitted many technical parts like floating point operations which were quite disappointing.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecture is not useful at all. The professor taught very slowly and sometimes digressed from the slides. In the end, I did not attend his lecture after the third chapter.

Instead, I somehow enjoy Johnny tutorial. He explained clearly and gave some insight. He also discussed exams homework.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading, to my surprise, is generous. Full mark in lab, 9x in homework and midterm and 7x in final. As the professor said the grading is absolute, I will not give the statistics parameters. Luckily, I got A

Some of the midterm questions are similar to the sample. No sample for final.
reviews.comment_workload:
Too light.

Just follow the instruction in the lab, copy and paste.

No need to worry about the exam as they just asked some simple questions. I didnt take this course seriously.

But you need to worry about how you answer. I am an open-minded person and I got a bad score in the final because I rather preferred analytical question instead of answering question taken directly from the slides. Moreover, there are some vague word in the question like "best solution" etc. Worst scenario, I did the same thing as Johnny had in the tutorial about drawing dependency and suprisingly they marked my answer wrong with some strange reasons.

reviews.author: app_Sci
reviews.title: A Relatively Hard Course
reviews.comment_content:
Contents before midterm:
1. MIPS instructions
2. Integer arithmetic (for PC)
3. Floating point number algebra (for PC)
4. Performance calculation (i.e. cycle per instruction, CPU speed, etc.)
Contents after midterm:
5. Single-cycle processor architecture
6. Multi-cycle pipelined processor architecture
7. Hazard detection within the pipelined processor.
In my opinion, 2 and 4 are easy. 3 is relatively a bit harder. 1 is again a little bit harder than 3. 5 is more difficult, 6 and 7 are the most difficult ones.
For contents before midterm, only assembly code is difficult. But after midterm, all contents are difficult. Suggested to have a good understanding.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I personally like the fact that Kursun emphasized what he think is important and might be confusing to us. However, he often clapped hands in class to wake people up. While that isn't bad per se, I just always feels kinda annoyed from his claps. Not a fan of it.
Johnny is very knowledgeable about the course, but he can be pretty impatient towards those who are a bit behind the course.
I did pretty crappy in midterm, and when i personally went to check papers, he is kinda impatient and annoyed towards my questions.
However, after my above-average performance in finals, I went to check paper again and his attitude improved siginficantly.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is satisfactory, not bad, not good. A score close to mean should grant you c+ or b-.
HW 10%
Lab 20%
Midterm 30%
Final 40%
HW1: Mean: 81.4/100 (Canvas) Me: 79.5/100
HW2: Mean: 72.7/100 (Canvas) Me: 75/100
Lab total mark: Mean: 480/500 (Canvas) Me: 447.5/500
(Somehow I got 83.5/100 in lab 4 and got a 64/100 in lab 5, didnt know how I did it but doesnt feel good.)
Midterm: Mean: 65/100 (Announcement) SD: 20-25~ish
               Me: 60.5/100
(30 marks of T&F)
Final: Mean 58.4/100 (Canvas) Me: 69/100 SD: >25 (Exact SD Unknown)
(Johnny said that the marks are pretty extreme. Some got single digit marks. Its kinda like if you knew what you are doing, you will get satisfactory performance.)
Expected a B or a B-.
Final Grade: B-
reviews.comment_workload:
Almost no workload for the labs. Must attend one of the two prelabs. Homework needs a bit of workload. The heaviest workload comes from the exams.
Overall not heavy but not light.

reviews.author: sam.yeunggg
reviews.comment_content:
This course mainly talks about MIPS processors. The difference between COMP2611 and ELEC2300 is the former focus more on software level and the latter focus more on hardware level.

Basic computer knowledge (e.g. what is an 'Embedded Computer' and examples), MIPS assembly code, computer arithmetic are the focus of Midterm Exam.

Single-cycle/Multi-cycle Architecture, Pipelining, Pipeline Hazards and memory (mainly about cache in processor) are in the scope of Final Exam.

C programming background is recommended, as Homework and Exam might see questions involving translating C to MIPS code.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Xu is very strict on people talking in lecture, other than that, he is quite nice and good at teaching the course.

Johnny is responsible for tutorials and labs. He is very nice, willing to help students out. Tutorials also guide us how to do the homeworks.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Homework (2 Total)
20% Laboratory (5 Total)
30% Midterm
40% Final

~80% in Homework
All lab scored full mark except one (94/100)
~above 0.5sd in both Midterm/Final
Got B
reviews.comment_workload:
2 Homeworks with moderate number of questions. Some of the questions TYPES might appear in the exam. They are not too difficult and Johnny will help you through if you really don't understand the questions.

2 Pre-lab sessions and 5 actual lab sessions. Pre-lab sessions are compulsory and not attending actual lab will just lose marks. Labs are quite easy, you just need to copy the data on the screen to the lab report sheet most of the time. Again, Johnny and other TAs will help you in the lab.

The workload is light considered it is a 4-credit course. You can skip lectures and read the notes on your own, but I recommend taking tutorials as it is more relevant to what exam will ask you.

reviews.author: butter New fly
reviews.comment_content: This course is about the most basic concepts of computer organization. It covers instructions of the computer, computer arithmetic, computer performance, single-cycle processor architecture, pipelined multi-cycle processor architecture and memory. The contents are relatively interesting and practical as well as essential for deeper electronic studies. As an introductory course, it could give me a basic understanding and raise my interest.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor gives very good and detailed explanation about most of the concepts. His tone of speaking makes it difficult to fall asleep, but this controversally as some friends are likely to sleep. He sometimes brings some manufactured sample ICs for us to get understanding. It is easy to find him to answer questions and it can really clear thoughts.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is generally considered not so satisfactory as it is absolute grading. However, the limit for each grade can be adjusted according to mean. The exams proved to be a bit difficult in total.

Homework- 10% (two in total)
Lab- 20% almost everyone can get full point without preparing for it
Midterm- 30% mean:71/100, sd:18
final- 40% mean:59/100, sd:18

Final has questions concerning memory that are difficult for beginners, and I believe reading the textbook could enhance understanding (but it's difficult to find time doing this).

Overall, I got more than 90% and A+, my friends with around mean+sd got A-.
reviews.comment_workload: Relatively light as no need to prepare for labs.

reviews.author: seeseesky
reviews.comment_content: Not many mathematics-related content, easy for students who like recite and weak at calculus. The courses is all about MIPS and how the hardwares inside a computer system work collaboratively.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecturer is good. He is funny and his explanation is quite detail. Maybe it is because the course is easy to understand. Tutors are good and willing to answer students' questions via email.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading, around 88% for A-range. Not difficult to get high mark but difficult to get A-range.
reviews.comment_workload: Typical workload. Having 2 assignments, labs every week. They are quite easy to handle.

reviews.author: fungsiu
reviews.comment_content: this course talk about assembly lang. Which is a low level language that can be easily understand by machine but harder for human to read. but still you can understand most of them. It talk about how would a command run in the computer in detail, and talk about calculating the efficiency of the machine.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Kursun is a good prof, he talk with clear english and his own powerpoint is incredible. You really dont need much revision for the exams or mid-term IF you attended all lesson and listened carefully and jot some notes.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is similar to all ELEC courses, which is generally good, you will probably got B- if u get mean.
reviews.comment_workload: Theres not much HW to do, about one per 2*-3 week. and the lab is not difficult, just follow the instrustions and the tutor will teach step by step

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.author: smallpotato tom
reviews.title: Fair Grading but Less Resources compared to COMP2611
reviews.comment_content:
MIPS, Performance, Single Cycle and Multi Cycle are the most important topics in 2300. No Memory lecture in this semester. In the beginning, I thought those content were quite difficult, unless I got old lecture resources (not powered by Kursun) and found that those things were easy and simple.

Sometimes "Source" is really important in EE world.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Bad.

Or I would say I hate Kursun's teaching style. He always requires us to stay absolute focus in the lessons. He is always angry. On the other hand, he can't control his rhythm in the lesson - sometimes too fast sometimes too slow.

His lecture notes are complex and orderless. Black and White. No key point.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got above mean around 6 to 10 marks in MT and Final.

3 labs of 5 got full marks.

Finally got a B. Not good not bad.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 Compulsory Labs, 1 Midterm, 1 Final.

No homework which can be good or bad. Less workload but less practices as well.

Note that no PP and PP are provided for 2 exams.
(Practice Paper and Past Paper :>)

For CPEG students, I highly recommend choosing COMP2611.

reviews.author: Duke of N.T.
reviews.comment_content: 全世界教Computer Organization都係用同一本書，所以冇咩好講，亦都係因為咁，上網攞料好方便。成個course分三部份：MIPS, Performance, Architecture。MIPS呢就programming啦，呢部份係最有趣嘅，對於你programming嘅手勢大有好處。而Performance就最容易嘅，背好幾條公式即可。Architecture明左Concept就OK，同MIPS有關係，所以務必要處理好MIPS嘅部份。
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof串串地，而且好有自己意見，唔多係一個好相處嘅人。例如同學九點堂恰眼訓，佢就會話：「返黎上堂就唔好訓，一係你返屋企訓之後睇返片。」又有次係臨落堂(佢堂堂都超時)，佢話：「我睇到有同學嘅眼神好不滿，咁不滿咪走先囉，我講緊重要嘅內容。」

教學方面，佢以自製嘅密密麻麻密集恐懼症powerpoint教書。同一樣野會講好多次，講到你唔想聽，不過勝在一定會明。

Johnny係好人，亦都好熟內容，不過佢教tutorial係好慢速唔多好聽的。
reviews.comment_grading: LAB次次滿分應該冇咩問題。
reviews.comment_workload: 不用預備的LAB，次次滿分。功課得兩份。

果5次Lab其實好易, 淨係跟Instruction去做, 小學畢業既都識做. 半粒鍾做得完.
